poem:
Crisis in Europe  

History leans, a weary gate,  
not all wars repeat the same fate—  
a tyrant's shadow casts anew,  
not Hitler's, yet agony grew.  
Clouds darken the eastern sky,  
a world mourns under fractured cry.  
Peace whispers through the storm's embrace,  
but echoes of the past cannot replace.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Putin is not Hitler. His actions in Ukraine are horrific enough to need no exaggeration | Simon Jenkins Is Vladimir Putin another Adolf Hitler? The western world seems to think so. In which case is Donald Trump another Neville Chamberlain and Ukraine another Czechoslovakia? Is history bunk, or is it a wise old man leaning on the gate as Europe storms into its latest crisis? Godwin’s law holds that the longer a political argument continues,". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
